If free will is defined as the existence of the possibility to consciously choose one out of many options, do human beings have free will? If you define free will as choice-making, then yes, clearly we all make choices. The problems arise out of what people mean by ‘free’. In the correct sense of the word, freedom implies the ability to make choices without coercion, and in that sense, also, yes, our choices are mostly free. However, our choice-making can never be truly free of influence. The choices we make reflect the sum total of all the influences that have formed us into what we are at the moment of making a choice. We cannot be free of that, because that is what we are. To be truly free of influence, would be to make random choices.
